Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Origin and Evolution of the X and Y Chromosomes in Stalk-eyed Flies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The distribution and organization of genes on chromosomes varies widely among animals. Chromosomes can change in number and size, as well as gene composition, over short evolutionary time scales. Furthermore, chromosome location can influence how genes are expressed. The aims of this project are to test alternative hypotheses for the origin and evolution of chromosome organization using diopsid flies as a model system. The research will focus on the genetic composition of the X and Y chromosomes. These chromosomes are responsible for much of the behavioral and physiological differences between males and females and are dynamic with respect to gene content. Also, preliminary research indicates that the X chromosome of diopsid flies is an autosome in other flies and, therefore, provides an opportunity to study how gene content and expression evolves on a newly derived X chromosome. The project will utilize advanced next-generation technology to identify a complete catalog of genes located on these chromosomes and their movements between species.

This project represents a collaboration between the University of Maryland, College Park (UMD) and the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH). The project will substantially enhance our understanding of the origin and evolution of new chromosomes and will influence scientific infrastructure by generating substantial genomic resources that will be made available through online databases. Training opportunities will be provided for students at all levels at both institutions. Finally, outreach will involve high school student interns at the AMNH and a high school teacher seminar series offered at UMD.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The distribution and organization of genes on chromosomes vary widely among animals and can change rapidly over short evolutionary time scales. Chromosome composition can also influence how genes are expressed in various tissues and how their DNA sequence evolves. The sex chromosomes, in particular, have a dynamic impact on gene movement, expression, and molecular evolution. In this project, we investigated how genes on the sex chromosomes influence reproduction and change location and expression over evolutionary time in a family of unusual insects called stalk-eyed flies. Stalk-eyed flies are remarkable because the male head is elongated into long stalks in numerous species. They have become an iconic system for studies of sexual differences and provide a natural experiment for studying sex chromosome evolution for several reasons: 1) a newly evolved X chromosome is present and not shared with other flies, 2) gene movement between sex chromosomes and autosomes is common and 3) distorted offspring sex ratios result when sex chromosomes are exposed to alternative genetic backgrounds in males. Our study used a comparative approach to determine when the new X chromosome arose in the history of these flies, how the presence of this new X chromosome influenced the origin of new genes, and what genetic changes cause extreme sex ratios.

We utilized next-generation transcriptome sequencing across numerous species found either in Southeast Asia or Africa to identify genes that are expressed in the reproductive tissues (i.e. testes and ovaries) of stalk-eyed flies and a novel DNA hybridization method to determine their chromosomal location. When examined in an evolutionary framework, the results indicate that the new X-chromosome arose prior to the diversification of the family, approximately 50 million years ago. More significantly, the X chromosome in these flies exhibits gene composition that is substantially different from the autosomes and from the X chromosomes that have been examined in other insects. We found that novel genes (i.e. genes that do not exist in other groups of flies) are created at an extremely high rate in stalk-eyed flies and are disproportionately located on the X chromosome. Most of these genes are also expressed exclusively within the testes. In contrast, previous studies on other insects have found that genes with male reproductive functions are underrepresented on the X chromosome. Also contrary to other studies, male reproductive genes are more likely to move off of an autosome and onto the X chromosome during the evolution of the family. These results suggest that the evolutionary and genomic factors making the X chromosome a hostile location for male genes in most insect systems are not important in stalk-eyed flies.

One primary mechanism that may be driving this genetic diversification is the presence of selfish X chromosomes that distorts the sex-ratio of carrier males. These X chromosomes have been found in natural populations of stalk-eyed flies and are expected to have a detrimental effect on the population. In extreme cases, they can cause population extinction. Results from our transcriptome sequencing and breeding experiments revealed that the sex-ratio distorter X chromosome is genetically differentiated from the normal X chromosome across nearly the entire chromosome. Furthermore, the new testes genes that have arisen on the X chromosome are more likely to exhibit expression difference between the normal and sex-ratio distorter flies than older genes, suggesting that the presence of the distorter element may be partially responsible for the formation and fixation of these new genes.
